results.title: The Kimberley: land of the Wandjina [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Hogarth, ABC-TV (Australia) and ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit
results.brief_description: Narrated by Leo McKern, this documentary, produced by the award-winning ABC TV Natural History Unit, explores the land and life of the spectacular Kimberley region of North West Australia. Aboriginal people believe that the Wandjina, the rain spirits, created the landscape. From the vast coastal mudflats to the tidal rivers and inland waterways, this beautifully photographed film explores in detail one of the least known regions of Australia.

results.title: Walking through a minefield
results.creator_credit: Cathy Henkel, Jeff Canin, Australian Film Commission, Hatchling Productions and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: A thought provoking documentary on the contentious issue of uranium mining, and in particular the construction of the new Jabiluka uranium mine by mining company Energy Resources of Australia (ERA) in the Kakadu National Park. The film follows the daily conflicts which face the dedicated protesters who have arrived, on invitation by the Aboriginal traditional owners, from all over Australia to set up a blockade to prevent ERA beginning construction at Jabiluka. Through interviews and personal commentary, the filmmakers present the many and varied viewpoints held by all those involved from all sides of the fence including ERA workers and management, protesters, Aboriginal traditional owners, police officers, tourist operators, and residents of the nearby town of Jabiru. Uranium mining has social, economical and political consequences for Australia and the Australian population particularly in light of the government’s intention to allow other mining companies to further develop our uranium industry. A very interesting and insightful program. Narrated by Rachel Griffiths.

results.title: The Nature of paradise
results.creator_credit: Lucinda Gamble, Daryl Dellora, John Moore, Sally Ingleton, Steve Thomas and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Three women - Trish Molloy (artist), Monique La Fontaine (artist), Sharon Wiggan (law student) - tell their stories, each from a personal perspective, of their relationship and connection to the Western Australian north-west coastal town of Broome. Trish and Monique are travellers who have separately found their way to Broome and stayed and Sharon is an Aboriginal Australian who was brought up in Broome, left to study in Perth and who has now returned home to Broome. The documentary explores each woman’s emotional and spiritual attachment to the town, to their surrounding environment and their kinship with the people of Broome and with each other. Evocative and beautifully photographed by Veronica Iacono, and sensitively scripted and directed by Lucinda Gamble, “The Nature of paradise” is stunningly rich in images and colour, of reds and blues, of the earth, sky and the ocean and is accompanied by an ambient musical soundtrack, “Free diving” written and performed by Lorrei Coffin. Interspersed throughout the documentary are images of both Trish and Monique’s paintings which reflect their transitional journey to this place called “paradise”.

results.title: Aboriginal dance: cultural reflections
results.brief_description: The environment has played an important role in Aboriginal society for thousands of years. The You Yangs (a big mountain in the middle of a plane) are a granite outcrop near Geelong that in the past has provided a food and water supply for the Wathaurong people. Art, music and dance provide an important outlet for the expression of culture, illustrated in this short documentary through the painting “Hunting and ceremonial grounds in the You Yangs” by Stan Couzens and in the performance of the Je Be Weng Dancers (Alan Browning, Casey Browning, Gordon Hollander, Christal Raymond). The Dancers perform 3 pieces - The Creation Dance, The Warrior Dance and The Celebration Dance. The significance of their body decoration and the movements depicted are also explained.

results.title: The Stolen generation: one man's story
results.brief_description: Brian Morley, Aboriginal singer/song writer, is searching for his “Dreamtime”. In 1960, at the age of two, along with his baby sister Jennifer and his older brother Shane, Brian was removed from the care of his natural mother in Dimboola by police and welfare and taken to the Turana Children’s Home in Melbourne. This is the story of Brian’s experiences growing up with a white adopted family, the long-term effects of being removed from his mother and separated from his brother and sister, and the search in his adulthood to find his family and define his Aboriginality. Brian eloquently relates his story in his own words and through his music, expressing hope for the future of all Australians and Australia. Narrated by Andy Johns. Teacher notes included.

results.title: Lois O'Donoghue
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Born in 1932, Lois O’Donoghue’s biography reads: Foundation Commission, Aboriginal Development Commission 1980-84, Australian of the Year, 1984, Chairperson, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, 1990 onwards. Speaking to interviewer Robin Hughes, Lois talks about her experience in being forcibly removed from her family as a young child and raised by strict missionaries. She also talks of the relationship with her mother that she was reunited with as an adult, domestic service, her attempt to gain access to a nursing career at the Royal Adelaide Hospital, involvement with the Aboriginal Advancement League, nursing in India with Baptist missionaries and her work as an administrator in Aboriginal Affairs. She also addresses race relations and her encounters with racism.

results.title: The Dreaming reels. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Volume II of a two volume set compiled by the National Film and Sound Archive (now ScreenSound Australia) containing a selection of silent Australian films, both factual and fictional, that focus on representations of Aboriginal peoples. This volume contains two feature length documentaries. “Coorab in the Island of ghosts” is believed to have been made from ethnographic footage shot on an early expedition by adventurer and overlander Francis Birtles. The material was edited and narrative intertitles added to give a ‘docudrama’ style, white interpretation of the life and tribal activities of an Aboriginal named Coorab, who lived around Cape York in Northern Australia. Despite its patronising tone the film presents a vivid picture of Aboriginal tribal life. “The Native problem in Queensland” is a silent documentary that was made for the Queensland Government which shows traditional tribal life and State institutions. It discusses the Government’s policy towards the native peoples of the state and is an official record of patrols to Queensland and Torres Strait reserves and missions by the Hon. E.M. Hanlon, Minister for Health and Home Affairs.

results.title: The Dreaming reels. Vol. 1
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Volume I of a two volume set compiled by the National Film and Sound Archive (now ScreenSound) containing a selection of early Australian films, both factual and fictional, that focus on representations of Aboriginal peoples. Early adventurers, explorers, scientists and ethnographers used motion picture cameras to record their travels in far flung reaches of Australia and their encounters with Aboriginal peoples often living traditional tribal lifestyles. The surviving footage reveals as much about the filmmakers as the subjects and expresses the prevailing attitudes of the day. Highlights include the Haddon expedition to the Torres Strait (possibly the world’s first ethnographic film in 1898) ; The Lake Tyres Aboriginal Settlement (1912) ; The Northwest Scientific and Exploration Syndicate in the Kimberley and North Western regions of Western Australia (1917) ; Australia’s first National Highway and the Aboriginal camp at Orbost (1921) ; The wonderland of West Australia, The Douglas Wylie Expedition (1926) ; Natives of Princess Charlotte Bay (Qld) filmed by South Australiam Museum (1926-27) ; Round Australia with the MacRobertson Expedition (1928). Seven feature films are represented with excerpts from “Moth of Moonbi”(1926), “The Enemy within” (1918), “Robbery under arms” (1920), “The Romance of Runnibede” (1927-28), “Trooper O’Brien” (1928), “The Birth of White Australia” and “The Tenth Straw”. Project consultant, Justine Saunders ; music, Jeff Evans.

results.title: Australia's journey: our first century as a nation
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Sally Jackson and ScreenSound Australia
results.brief_description: Commencing with Federation and the birth of a nation on 1 January 1901, this wonderful video captures the very essence of Australia and its people over 100 years, politically, socially, historically and environmentally. It manages to cover all aspects of Australian life from the city to the outback, from arts and entertainment to sport, from industry to technology, from the person on the street to the legends and heroes, from bushfires and droughts to floods and cyclones, from wars to peace, from civil rights protests to reconciliation. Through a compilation of archival film, television and newsreel footage the viewer is taken on a sentimental journey of historic events including WWI, WWII, 1956 Olympic Games, the railway linking of Australia’s east coast to the west coast, Royal visits, the birth of Canberra, along with glimpses of many famous faces such as Prime Ministers James Scullin, Billy Hughes, John Curtin, Gough Whitlam; sporting heroes Dawn Fraser, Sir Donald Bradman; actors and entertainers Errol Flynn, Lottie Lyall, Frank Thring Snr, Dame Edna, Mo, Ada and Elsie and much more. A most comprehensive and informative program. Contains b&w footage. Narrated by Amanda Keller.

results.title: Cry from the heart: the stolen generation
results.creator_credit: Jeni Kendell, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Gaia Films
results.brief_description: A confronting documentary which discusses the experiences of one Aboriginal family as a result of the Australian government’s policy in the first 70 years of the 20th Century of removing mixed Aboriginal children from their Aboriginal families and placing them in institutions or foster homes. The impact on thousands of Aboriginal families of being cut off from each other, their language and culture is evoked here in a very personal context. One family journey’s through the remembrance of the trauma of separation, confronting the consequences of it on their lives and the gradual process of being reunited and grieving for those family members they have lost. The progress of one family member is traced in detail from youth to time in jail to his release and his efforts to come to terms with his past and hopes for the future. Contains extensive interviews with family members, aboriginal support group leaders, and foster family members among others.
results.title_for_label: Cry from the heart: the stolen generation
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeni Kendell, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Gaia Films
results.description: A confronting documentary which discusses the experiences of one Aboriginal family as a result of the Australian government’s policy in the first 70 years of the 20th Century of removing mixed Aboriginal children from their Aboriginal families and placing them in institutions or foster homes. The impact on thousands of Aboriginal families of being cut off from each other, their language and culture is evoked here in a very personal context. One family journey’s through the remembrance of the trauma of separation, confronting the consequences of it on their lives and the gradual process of being reunited and grieving for those family members they have lost. The progress of one family member is traced in detail from youth to time in jail to his release and his efforts to come to terms with his past and hopes for the future. Contains extensive interviews with family members, aboriginal support group leaders, and foster family members among others.
